Hello
If c3 is simply c1+c2 you should just make it an auxiliary variable.
That will make the nonlinear system smaller and easier to solve
Guillaume

node.title: What method computes nodal forces / moments in beam
node.bodyText: Hello. I am looking for method, which computes force / moment values in the nodes of line element. ComputeBeamResultants::computeQpProperties() gives their values in q-points, but what about nodal values. Please help me to find it.

Hello
What are force and moment stored as? Material properties?
Or are you computing them yourself from other quantities? (And in this case, what are they stored as?)
Guillaume

Thank you, @GiudGiud . Force and moment in q-points stored as material properties

It computed from strains in ComputeIncrementalBeamStrain::computeQpStrain()
But it all about qp-Forces
i can't find where nodal forces are computed, maybe in StressDivergenceBeam ?
The tagged residual vector should be the reaction forces and moments.
Thank you @hugary1995, @GiudGiud.

node.title: material derivative w.r.t gradvar
node.bodyText:
Hi
I want to implement porosity change as a function of strain:
$$ \phi = 1 - (1-\phi_0) \exp^{-\epsilon} $$
(*_dporosity_dvar)[_qp][v] = (1-phi0)*std::exp(-vol_strain) 

(*_dporosity_dgradvar)[_qp][v]  = how?

how to calculate the derivative with respect gradient?

Hello
Do you mean in terms of math or moose?
For the math I d Taylor expand the expression then that makes the gradient appear and you can take the derivative there
For MOOSE you can retrieve derivative of material properties the same way as you retrieve material properties. You just need to have defined that derivative material property somewhere else
Guillaume

node.title: Error of installing WASP in offline installation of moose
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am installing moose by offline way.
When i come the the step (the previous steps go well)

./update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh --skip-submodule-update

I get the following error

CMake Error: Unknown argument --skip-submodule-update
CMake Error: Run 'cmake --help' for all supported options.
Error: configure step for WASP failed to complete successfully

And at this time, my dir */moose/framework/contrib/wasp has nothing but an empty /build.
Could you please give me some advice? Thanks!

@brandonlangley do you have offline installation instructions for wasp?
@bylore you ll need to download wasp online then make that available in the offline environment

I find the installation instructions for wasp in
https://code.ornl.gov/neams-workbench/wasp/-/tree/master?ref_type=heads#requirements
But i can't access https://code-int.ornl.gov/profile/keys
for the first step Save the ssh-key in [code-int.ornl.gov](https://code-int.ornl.gov/profile/keys).
Online HPC-Cluster way works for me. Thank you.

HELLO
I have the same error as you,and I plan to install moose offline on centos.Your link I can not open,.I want to know how you solve.

@ljeft you can copy and paste the above link in your browser. I give up the offline installation and choose online way
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/hpc_install_moose.html

@bylore @ljeft -
Running ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh from the MOOSE root will configure and build the shared libs for MOOSE.
If necessary, you can clone WASP and its submodules yourself then configure, build, and install the components for MOOSE.
Run git submodule status | grep wasp from the MOOSE source to get the WASP SHA compatible for your MOOSE, then:
git clone https://code.ornl.gov/neams-workbench/wasp.git path/to/wasp/source
cd path/to/wasp/source
git reset --hard SHA-FROM-STEP-ABOVE
git submodule update --init

I'm not very familiar with CentOS, but to build WASP yourself the CMake configure before compiling will be something like:
cmake \
  -D CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE:STRING=RELEASE \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_ALL_PACKAGES:BOOL=OFF \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_wasphit:BOOL=ON \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_wasplsp:BOOL=ON \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_waspsiren:BOOL=ON \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_testframework:BOOL=OFF \
  -D wasp_ENABLE_TESTS:BOOL=OFF \
  -D BUILD_SHARED_LIBS:BOOL=ON \
  -D DISABLE_HIT_TYPE_PROMOTION:BOOL=ON \
  -D CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=path/to/wasp/install \
  path/to/wasp/source

After configuring with the above options, you can run make install to install the WASP components needed for MOOSE.
When building MOOSE, you'll need to make sure the WASP_DIR environment variable is set to your path/to/wasp/install.
That $WASP_DIR install directory should contain at least the include and lib subdirectories.

@brandonlangley
I followed your advice and manually cloned WASP and its submodules. Then I followed the offline installation tutorial, uploaded the package to the system where I wanted to install moose, ran./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh, and still got the same error.cmake version

CMake Error: The source directory "/public/home/ghfund3_a47/projects/moose/framework/contrib/wasp/build/--skip-submodule-update" does not exist.
Specify --help for usage, or press the help button on the CMake GUI.
Error: configure step for WASP failed to complete successfully

Hello
I think you tried to pass a --skip-submodule-updated flag but it was either not done properly or it s not supported so please just remove it and try again
Guillaume

@ljeft @GiudGiud -
Using --skip-submodule-update is currently problematic because that flag gets passed in as a configure option.
This has been reported as an issue and needs to be fixed - #25821
As mentioned in the issue, until this is fixed a workaround is to export SKIP_SUBMODULE_UPDATE=1 before running script.
And then do not pass the --skip-submodule-update flag when running ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh.

node.title: Applying computeJacobian and computeOffDiagJacobian
node.bodyText: Hello. Help me please to understand what difference between these two methods. I need to override it's implementation in StressDivergenceBeam but i don't entirely understand their application.

computeJacobian is for the block-diagonal of the Jacobian while computeOffDiagJacobian is for the off-diagonal terms (coupling between different variables)
There s more information there
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Kernels/index.html
block diagonal to be 100% clear

Thank you, @GiudGiud, @lindsayad.
In ComputeIncrementalBeamStrain::computeStiffnessMatrix()  entities
_K11(declareProperty<RankTwoTensor>("Jacobian_11")),
_K21_cross(declareProperty<RankTwoTensor>("Jacobian_12")),
_K21(declareProperty<RankTwoTensor>("Jacobian_21")),
_K22(declareProperty<RankTwoTensor>("Jacobian_22")),
_K22_cross(declareProperty<RankTwoTensor>("Jacobian_22_cross"))

are computed:
for example _K22[0] = _total_rotation[0].transpose() * K22_local * _total_rotation[0];
i consider that as global stiffness entities for element , is it right?
Then in StressDivergenceBeam::computeJacobian() _local_ke is filling by these elements
So what is difference between global stiffness matrix and  _local_ke which "Holds local Jacobian entries" as described  ?

@GiudGiud , @lindsayad. Help me please to understand what data _local_ke holds.
The desription is the next:
Holds local Jacobian entries as they are accumulated by this Kernel
I can't understand what is local Jacobian entries
I think, that  _K22[0] = _total_rotation[0].transpose() * K22_local * _total_rotation[0];
is transformation of stiffness matrix from local to global coordinates, so  _K22[0] must be entity
of global stiffness matrix isn't it. Please correct me if i am not right.
@GiudGiud, thank you for your answer.
@cbolisetti , what do think about this?

block diagonal to be 100% clear

Is this related to computeOffDiagJacobian ?

related to computeJacobian.
As opposed to off-block-diagnoal for computeOffDiagJacobian that looks at the coupling between variables
Thank you, @GiudGiud. What are you think about Jacobian Entities: #26107 (reply in thread)

I think there is some global-local confusion here. The 'global stiffness matrix' you are referring to is in the global co-ordinate system but its just for that specific element the kernel is operating on. The local in _local_ke does not refer to a co-ordinate system. Its only saying that it is local to this element. But it is also in the global co-ordinate system. Therefore the stiffness matrix of the element in the global co-ordinate system is fed into _local_ke. @GiudGiud please correct me if I am wrong.
@cbolisetti, thank you, now it's clearer for me.
Great. Sorry for the late responses.

node.title: How to control execution order of MOOSE objects
node.bodyText:
Hello, I'm new to MOOSE, and have a problem on developping a MOOSE application. I applied the Monte Carlo code OpenMC to generate few-group cross sections which used for reactor physics simulations by the MOOSE-based application. The OpenMC was compiled into a dynamic libarary and implemented in MOOSE's material system to generate the few-group cross sections. In an eigenvalue problem, I found that the construction function of the material system derived object were executed by three times, i. e., OpenMC were executed by three times which should have been executed once enough to generated the few-group cross sections. Then, I changed the location of OpenMC routines in the derived object but cannot fix this problem well.
Moreover, I want to compute discontinuous factors of fuel assemblies which needs to sovle the eigenvalue problem and get solutions. The residuals for convergence should be computed from errors between the solutions from MOOSE solver and the reference results from OpenMC. I don't konw how to achieve this iteration loop by using the core framework of MOOSE.
For both of the problems, the key is that I don't know how to control the execution orders of MOOSE objects. Could you give me some instructions?

Hello
Materials are executed three times for the local element, the neighbor element and the face value (or something related, I d have to check that one)
I'm not sure we have a way to control that.
I would think openmc would be run in a user object instead, once for the whole simulation and not once per element?
Is once per element really what you want?
Guillaume

Thanks for your answer. As you say, I tried that runing openmc in a user object and getting data from the user object into a material object. In the user object, OpenMC was initialied in initialize() and excuted in execute() derived from the GeneralUserObject. The generated cross sections were got by computeQpProperties() in the material object. But I found that  computeQpProperties() was executed before the user object and changing the execte_on flag in an input file didn't work. What's the problem?
You can use Debug/show_execution_order=ALWAYS to see when the user object is being executed
That is expected. If you cannot put the openmc call inside the constructor or initialSetup of the user object, you will need to manage the execute_on parameter very carefully.
Thank you very much for your instructions, I fixed this problem by moving openmc routine into a user object's construction function and omitting the override of initialize/execute/finalize.

Thanks for your reply, this paper is truly helpful to my work. But what makes me confused mostly is how to implement algorithms of computing DFs by using moose. To solve different types of problem in moose, the Executioner/type is set as Eigenvalue/Steady and so on. In algorithm-1 of the reference paper, an eigenvalue calculation and steady-state iterations need to be done. I don't know how to achieve a complex algorithm by combining and ordering several solving routines based on the moose coding framework. Could you give me some suggestions?

DF calculation is not an eigenvalue calculation. With moose, we cast it into a nonlinear problem that has DFs depend on fluxes and DFs affect the solution, i.e. fluxes. The residual R(phi) can be represented as Tr[DF(phi)](phi), where Tr is implemented with your transport kernel, same as eigenvalue calculations, except the DGKernel needs to couple in DF. For this "nonlinear" problem, the solution is still fluxes without source, but it can have a non-trivial solution (nonzero solution). Once we obtained the fluxes, we can get DFs. We can use Steady executioner to solve this which implements a PJFNK (preconditioned Jcobian-free Newton-Krylov) solver. The initial guess could be tricky but typically a flat initial solution is good for the PJFNK solver converging to the solution.
Thank you very much, I will try it.

I'm sorry to bother you again, but I'm getting stucked in the implementation of DF calculation for two weeks. The problem is that non-physical (negative and asymmetry) solutions always occur. By checking codes carefully, I found that the error was caused by solving the neutron diffusion equation with Steady executioner in which a keff is fixed and comes from a reference solution. But the correct solutions can be obtained by Eigenvalue executioner. The difference between the mentioned two calculation is mainly the implementation of Kernel for the fission source term in the neutron diffusion equation. I checked it carefully and no mistakes were found in the fission kernel. Could you give me some advices?

Your fission kernel must be able to accept a scaling factor for 1/k typically in a postprocessor. With Eigenvalue, MOOSE will scale the fission kernel automatically. But with Steady, you will need to do the scaling manually. I hope this is the issue.
Thank you, I fixed it.

Thanks for the logs.

Both are on GMGs that are very reasonable tets in a rectangular grid and I checked with the diagnostics generator and I dont get any on my machine.
For the p_refinement error you are running one version of PETSc behind us so the first thing I would do is update the whole stack and try again

Thanks for your help!
But how should I update my PETSc?
I already used the following command:
mamba update --all

That should have done it.
You can try
mamba update moose-dev

what does
mamba list | grep moose

return

The proximate cause of the negative Tet14 Jacobians is that node 4 and 5 are in the same place; that's almost always a huge no-no.
The underlying cause of that is probably the bug which was fixed a couple months ago in libMesh/libmesh#3649
And that means the root cause is probably a newer MOOSE being built against an older libMesh.

This is still using PETSc 3.19.3, so I echo the others in saying that your packages are out of date. Given the hash of MOOSE you are running, please perform the following command in your conda MOOSE environment:
mamba install moose-dev=2023.11.10

In order to have a complete set of up-to-date conda packages compatible with your MOOSE version. Then, you should perform a make clobberall in your test directory and build/test MOOSE again.

Thanks for your guidance! It works!
It seems that I am using an older version of the conda MOOSE environment causing the problem.
The wired thing is that when I use the two following commands, I can't successfully update the environment:
mamba update --all
mamba update moose-dev

Only I perform the following command it works:
mamba install moose-dev=2023.11.10

How should I update my conda MOOSE environment correctly? Is there any way I can follow?
The 2nd one is the right way but sometimes it fails so then we use the last one like you did
Ah, got it! Thank you very much! Have a nice day!

node.title: Open-to-flow boundary condition implementation.
node.bodyText:
Hi
I want to solve CO2 infection problem in a brine-saturated reservoir:


How can implement open-to-flow boundaries as:

Here primary variables are pgas, zi, and xnacl.  Initially, the reservoir is fully saturated with brine(Xnacl=0.1).

[BCs]
  # Left pgas = No flow
  [top_pgas]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = pgas
    value = 5e6  # 5 MPa
    boundary = 'top'
  []
  [top_zi]
    type = DirichletBC   # or PorousFlowOutflowBC ??
    variable = zi
    value = 0  
    boundary = 'top'
  []
  [top_xnacl]
    type = DirichletBC  # or PorousFlowOutflowBC ??
    variable = xnacl
    value = 0.1 
    boundary = 'top'
  []
[]


For outflow, which one would be more appropriate here: DirichletBC  # or PorousFlowOutflowBC ??
Thank you!

Hello
DirichletBC are appropriate for pressure at the top I think.
For flow I would not expect to set the concentration on the boundary. Especially free-flow.
@cpgr may want to pitch in, though did you check if there's an example of this in the module?
Guillaume

I would try Dirichlet for pressure and temperature at the top and bottom (and I guess a function Dirichlet on the right hand side), and the PorousFlowOutflowBC for the other variables. I'm not sure what they mean by constant saturation though - if gas phase CO2 can reach a boundary and flow out then the saturation will change at that boundary?

In the paper pgas and sgas are used as the primary variable and a constant saturation is applied.
I tried the BCs as you mentioned...simulation runs okay for a few steps but it seems CO2 saturation fronts don't move forward and pressure increases too much and at the end getting pressure must be less than 60 MPa and non-linear solution doesn't converge. Here is my input and mesh file...would you please have a look?
https://github.com/anupkgeos/moose_co2_test/blob/main/5cappa2011a_2comp_simple.i
https://github.com/anupkgeos/moose_co2_test/blob/main/cappa2011_simple.msh
Sorry about the late reply! I think your injection rate is too high - it is integrated over the boundary. Did you mean for this to be a cylindrical model? At the moment, it is only 2D.

node.title: Possible bug in computation of second time derivative
node.bodyText:
I think I may have found a bug in the computation of the second time derivative of an array kernel's variable. If I define a simple kernel of the form:
ArrayTestKernel.h
#pragma once

#include "ArrayKernel.h"

class ArrayTestKernel : public ArrayKernel{

    public:
        ArrayTestKernel( const InputParameters & params );

        static InputParameters validParams( );

    protected:

        const ArrayVariableValue & _u_dot;

        const ArrayVariableValue & _u_dotdot;

        virtual void computeQpResidual( RealEigenVector &residual ) override;

};

ArrayTestKernel.C
#include "ArrayTestKernel.h"

registerMooseObject( "fireflyApp", ArrayTestKernel );

InputParameters ArrayTestKernel::validParams( ){

    InputParameters params = ArrayKernel::validParams( );

    return params;

}

ArrayTestKernel::ArrayTestKernel( const InputParameters & parameters )
    : ArrayKernel( parameters ),
    _u_dot( _var.uDot( ) ),
    _u_dotdot( _var.uDotDot( ) ){

}

void ArrayTestKernel::computeQpResidual( RealEigenVector & residual ){

    std::cerr << "_u_dot:\n" << _u_dot[ _qp ] << "\n";
    std::cerr << "_u_dotdot:\n" << _u_dotdot[ _qp ] << "\n";

    return;

}

If I run this with Newmark-Beta integration to enable the second time derivative using
my_test.i
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 1
  nx = 3
[]

[Variables]
  [u]
    components = 2
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [test]
    type = ArrayTestKernel
    variable = u
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
  [u_diffusion]
    type = ArrayDiffusion
    variable = u
    diffusion_coefficient = u_dc
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
  [u_time]
    type = ArrayTimeDerivative
    variable = u
    use_displaced_mesh = false
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [u]
    type = ArrayFunctionIC
    variable = u
    function = '.3*(-x+y-0.1*z) 0.19*(-x+y+z)'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [u_dc]
    type = GenericConstantArray
    prop_name = u_dc
    prop_value = '1 1'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./smp]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  dt = 0.1
  dtmin = 0.1
  num_steps = 3
  scheme = newmark-beta
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_test_jacobian -snes_test_jacobian_view'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Then I get that _u_dot is exactly the same as _u_dotdot for all increments and iterations. This same approach works okay for non-array variables. Can anyone see where I've gone awry here or is this actually a problem in MOOSE?

Hello
I think you may be the first one to look at array variables and second time derivatives.
Can you please try a simple time integrator instead of NewmarkBeta first?
Guillaume
@GiudGiud Do any of the other implicit time integrators make the second time derivatives available?
Does not look like it. CentralDifference is explicit iirc and has 2nd time derivatives

Okay, so I don't think I can use anything other than Newmark-Beta. I tried to use setUDotDotRequested(true) in the constructor of ArrayKernelTest but that fails.
The only classes that I could find that request the second time derivative are time integrators so I don't have much to follow.
I ll try to drum up something with BDF2

Seems to happen as well with a simple backwards difference for the second time derivative with BDF2
https://github.com/GiudGiud/moose/tree/PR_second

The computation seems to be correct for BDF2. But the kernel prints the wrong value. We're missing something.
@hugary1995 @cbolisetti any idea

We still calculate second time derivative using NewmarkBetaAccelAux auxkernel in a lot of cases, instead of using the time integrator. It should work for any variable, I think. Its probably the simplest way for your case.

node.title: How to know how many layers of adaptivity have been applied at a specific quadrature point?
node.bodyText: Hi, I want to apply different levels of adaptivity w.r.t. different variables. Say, if I want to apply 5 layers of adaptivity to variable u and 3 layers of adaptivity to variable v by ValueRange marker, I will need to stop marking v as 'refine' if 3 layers of adaptivity are already applied. I will modify the source file 'ValueRangeMarker.C' by myself, yet how should I know the adaptivity level?

Hello
Do you mean the current local adaptivity level for an element?
Can you use this to combine two markers?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/markers/ComboMarker.html
Guillaume

Hi, I know how to combine them, yet the maximize level of refinement is defined by 'max_h_level'. I want to apply different maximum levels to these two markers, yet I don't know how to obtain the current level.

for a given element, you can get the level of adaptivity with elem->level()
see the doxygen
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/docs/doxygen/libmesh/classlibMesh_1_1Elem.html#a9c0282a545257463ba99b1cbb7f9752d
then in a custom marker you can have logic that checks the level before marking

It sounds like you want a different refinement level for each variable? That is not possible. The level of refinement is stored on a per-element basis and applies uniformly to the variables in the equation systems. There is a capability to do selective p-refinement, but even there you can only totally disable p-refinement for a variable; there is no option to only (p-)refine a variable up to a certain amount
Hi @lindsayad, I actually want to apply different max_h_level to two markers. I think @GiudGiud just provided me what I want. Thank you both! I will try to implement it now.
excellent!
